A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like: Half a star is too generous... Interesting that almost a week after release\, Disney claims the poor audience ratings on Rotten Tomatoes are due to trolling/bombing... Well\, that prompted me to add my tuppence worth: the film was dire. I hated the prequels\, but I still always felt like the prequels had integrity; TLJ has neither integrity nor credibility. I've been a fan since '77\, and when Disney took over the helm\, I had an open mind - I truly enjoyed TFA\, and Rogue One even more. But TLJ? There were some good performances from the cast\, young and old\, but the writing was dreadful\, and so un-Star Wars. Some of the people who like the film dismiss those who hate it by saying that the latter aren't open to new directions and ideas. It isn't true - the 'haters' just aren't open to sh*t directions and directing\, and sh*t ideas. Flying Leia\, the boring subplot (Finn & Rosie) to a boring chase through space\, misused Luke\, Holdo's decision-making (or lack of)\, \"Godspeed\"\, the constant stream of cheesy jokes\, the plot holes bigger than a galaxy far\, far way... Is TLJ meant to be a spoof or parody of the franchise? Perhaps a more honest title would've been Spaceballs: The Last Jedi. When I saw it\, on opening day at Odeon Leicester Sq in London\, the audience sat silent; at the end\, there was polite clapping only for the dedication to Carrie Fisher. Afterwards\, I spoke to the people sat next to me\, and to others on the way out; everyone of them was disappointed with the film\, nobody smiled... Star Wars had been a huge part of me until now\, so stand up and take a bow Johnson\, Kennedy and Disney. Thanks to you\, I'm over it!
